ygData.subject: Re: New HyperNEAT Paper in the Domain of Checkers
ygData.msgSnippet: Yes true, that is something to consider.  Direct connections are often useful as well and without z there would need to be perhaps another output for those.

Yes true, that is something to consider.  Direct connections are often
usef=
ul as well and without z there would need to be perhaps another
output for =
those.  In any case, one of our aims was to make this
implementation simple=
 in part so that it would be easy to understand
for the broader AAAI commun=
ity.  That is also why we did not use
biases, even though we can do that as=
 well with an additional CPPN
output (and we have had success doing it that=
 way).  So we are hoping
with this paper to really motivate the concept to =
people who would
otherwise find it too far outside their area.

All of the =
many ways a CPPN can be used to represent a network
structure are certainly=
 worth exploring.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <pe=
tar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> Sorry for this double-post, but if you don't=
 allow direct input-
> >output connections and probably recurrent connectio=
ns (such that go 
> from one hidden node to another one in the same layer),=
 then you have 
> made assumptions for a layered network topology. I guess =
that such a 
> topology (space) is enough to solve the problem, but it rest=
ricts the 
> real power of the CPPN, to describe any possible topology. 
> =

> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Jason Gauci" <jgmath2000@> wrot=
e:
> >
> > Regarding the number of connections, there are two things to not=
e:
> > 
> > First, HyperNEAT uses all 64 input nodes, even the ones which c=
annot
> > legally contain a piece.  The reason why is because we wanted to
=
> > compare HyperNEAT's approach to discovering geometric regularities
> > =
with NEAT-EI's approach of using a priori engineered regularities.  
> If
>=
 > we disabled the connections that would never be activated, we would 
> b=
e
> > cheating, in a sense, by providing a priori domain-specific 
> knowle=
dge
> > to the algorithm.  The only a priori knowledge needed involves the
=
> > size of the layers in the substrate and the hidden layer
> > configurat=
ion.  In this case, the extra connections have no impact 
> on
> > the netw=
ork, but I left them in ti keep with the spirit of the 
> experiment.
> > 
=
> > Second, all 64*64 + 64*1 (4160) connections in the substrate are not
> =
> always expressed.  If the CPPN outputs a value with a magnitude less
> > =
than 0.2, the connection weight is forced to absolute 0, disabling 
> the
>=
 > connection.  Connections which are disabled are considered to not
> > ex=
ist, so the 3979 number implies that some of the connections were
> > not e=
xpressed in that substrate.
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Stephen W=
aits <steve@> wrote:
> > >
> > > 
> > > On Apr 11, 2008, at 9:38 PM, Kennet=
h Stanley wrote:
> > > > Jason Gauci and I are pleased to share with you ne=
w results with
> > > > HyperNEAT  in our new paper to appear in the Twenty-=
Third AAAI
> > > > Conference on Artificial Intelligence (2008), "A Case St=
udy on 
> the
> > > > Critical Role of Geometric Regularity in Machine Lear=
ning."
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Cool, I enjoyed the paper, thanks Jason and Ken.=

> > > 
> > > I have a few questions:
> > > 
> > > * Was the 4in/2out CPPN =
arbitrarily chosen?
> > > * Why not a 6in/1out (xyz, xyz, out) - which seem=
s more natural 
> to me?
> > > * Was more than one CPPN configuration tried=
?  What was the 
> process?
> > > * Was more than one substrate configurati=
on tried?  ...
> > > * What was the full connection pattern through the sub=
strate?  
> You  
> > > mention the 129 nodes (which makes sense), but what=
 are the 3979  
> > > connections?
> > > * Did you try against any opponent=
s other than Xcheckers?
> > > * Have you experimented with coevolution?
> >=
 > 
> > > Thanks again for the great work.
> > > --
> > > Stephen Waits

 > steve@
